sen.j: 綏靖天皇（すいぜいてんのう、神武天皇29年（紀元前632年?）- 綏靖天皇33年5月10日 (旧暦)（紀元前549年6月28日?））は、日本の第2代の天皇（在位：綏靖天皇元年1月8日 (旧暦)（紀元前581年2月23日?） - 同33年5月10日 (旧暦)（紀元前549年6月28日?））。
sen.e: The Emperor Suizei (632 B.C. (?) to June 28, 549 B.C. (?)) was the second emperor (tenure: February 23, 581 B.C. (?) to June 28, 549 B.C. (?)) of Japan.
Emperor Suizei (632 B.C. (?) to June 28, 549 B.C. (?)) was the second emperor (tenure: February 23, 581 B.C. (?) to June 28, 549 B.C. (?)) of Japan.
Emperor Suizei (632 B.C. ? - June 28, 549 B.C. ?) was the second emperor (tenure: February 23, 581 B.C. ? - June 28, 549 B.C. ?) of Japan.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と表記を合わせました。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』では神渟名川耳尊（かむぬなかわみみのみこと）,『古事記』では神沼河耳命（かむぬなかわみみのみこと）ともいう。
sen.e: The Emperor Suizei was otherwise called Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto in a book, Nihon-shoki (the Chronicles of Japan) and a book, Kojiki (Ancient Chronicle) though the Chinese characters used for the name differed by book.

Emperor Suizei was otherwise called Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto in a book, Nihon-shoki (the Chronicles of Japan) and a book, Kojiki (Ancient Chronicle) though the Chinese characters used for the name differed by book.

Emperor Suizei is also called Kamunuka Kawamimi no Mikoto in both "Nihon Shoki" (The Chronicles of Japan) and "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), although different Chinese characters are used in these two documents.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 綏靖天皇という呼称は、奈良時代後期の文人である淡海三船が歴代天皇の諡を一括撰進したときに付されたとされる。
sen.e: It is said that the name, Emperor Suizei was given when Mifune AWAMI who was an accomplished writer in late Nara Period collectively selected the names to be given to the chronological order of the dead Emperors.

It is said that the name, Emperor Suizei was given when Mifune AWAMI who was an accomplished writer in late Nara Period collectively selected the names to be given to the chronological order of the dead Emperors.

It is said that the name, Emperor Suizei was given when Mifune AWAMI who was an accomplished writer during the late Nara period collectively selected names to be given in chronological order to the dead Emperors.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と表記を合わせました。

sen.j: いわゆる欠史八代の1人で、実在しない天皇と捉える見方が一般的である（実在説もある）。
sen.e: The Emperor Suizei was one of so-called eight missing generations in the history and it is the general opinion that the Emperor Suizei did not actually exist (however, there is also an opinion that this emperor actually existed).

Emperor Suizei was one of the so-called eight generations missing from history and it is generally held that Emperor Suizei did not actually exist (however, there is also an opinion that this emperor actually existed).

Emperor Suizei was one of the so-called eight generations missing from history and it is generally held that Emperor Suizei did not actually exist (however, there is also an opinion that this emperor actually existed).

sen.j: 事績
sen.e: Achievements
Achievements
Achievements

sen.j: 神武天皇42年（紀元前619年?）に立太子。
sen.e: The Emperor Suizei was celebrated his investiture as a Crown Prince in 619 B.C. (?).
Emperor Suizei celebrated his investiture as Crown Prince in 619 B.C. (?).
Emperor Suizei celebrated his investiture as Crown Prince in 619 B.C. (?).

sen.j: 同76年（紀元前585年?）3月に神武天皇が崩御。
sen.e: The Emperor Jinmu died in March 585 B.C.(?)
Emperor Jinmu died in March 585 B.C.(?)
Emperor Jinmu died in March 585 B.C.(?)

sen.j: 神武天皇崩御後、タギシミミの反逆が発生。
sen.e: After the Emperor Jinmu died, a coup by Tagishimimi occurred.
After Emperor Jinmu died, a coup by Tagishimimi occurred.
After Emperor Jinmu died, a coup by Tagishimimi occurred.

sen.j: 都を葛城高丘宮(現在の奈良県御所市か？)に移す
sen.e: The Emperor Suizei moved the capital to Kazuraki-no-Takaoka-no-miya (presently, Mitokoro City in Nara Prefecture?).
Emperor Suizei moved the capital to Kazuraki-no-Takaoka-no-miya (presently, Mitokoro City in Nara Prefecture?).
Emperor Suizei moved the capital to Kazuraki-no-Takaoka-no-miya (presently, Mitokoro City in Nara Prefecture?).

sen.j: 詳細はタギシミミの反逆を参照
sen.e: See "Coup by Tagishimimi" for more detail
See "Coup by Tagishimimi" for more detail
See "Coup by Tagishimimi" for more detail.
sen.cmt: ピリオドを補足しました。

sen.j: 父・神武天皇が崩じた後、朝政の経験に長けていた庶兄の手研耳命（たぎしみみのみこと）が、腹違いの弟たちを害そうとした。
sen.e: After the Emperor Jinmu, the father of the Emperor Suizei died, Tagishimimi-no-mikoto who was an elder brother of his father's mistress and who had more experienced and was good at the politics in the Imperial Court tried to kill his younger half brothers.

After Emperor Jinmu, the father of Emperor Suizei died, Tagishimimi-no-mikoto who was an elder brother of his father's mistress and who had more experience and was proficient in the politics in Imperial Court politics tried to kill his younger half brothers.

After Emperor Jinmu, the father of Emperor Suizei died, Tagishimimi-no-mikoto who was an elder brother of his father's mistress and who had more experience and was proficient in the politics in Imperial Court politics tried to kill his younger half brothers.

sen.j: 神渟名川耳尊は母の歌からこのことを察知し、同母兄の神八井耳命（かむやいみみのみこと）とともに片丘（現在の奈良県北葛城郡王寺町）の大窖にいる手研耳を襲い、これを討った。
sen.e: Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto sensed this plan from his mother's tanka poem and he together with Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto, his elder brother of the same mother attacked Tagishimimi-no-mikoto who stayed in Oanagu of Kataoka (presently, Oji-cho in Kitakazuraki-gun in Nara Prefecture) and killed Tagishimimi-no-mikoto.

Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto sensed this plan from his mother's tanka poem and he together with Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto, his elder brother of the same mother attacked Tagishimimi-no-mikoto who stayed in Oanagu of Kataoka (presently, Oji-cho in Kitakazuraki-gun in Nara Prefecture) and killed Tagishimimi-no-mikoto.

Kamununakawamimi no Mikoto was informed of this plan through a poem written by his mother, and together with Kamuyaimimi no Mikoto, his elder brother born of the same mother, he attacked Tagishimimi no Mikoto in his home in Kataoka (present-day Oji-cho in Kitatsuragi-gun, Nara Prefecture).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: この際、神八井耳は恐怖で手足が震えおののいて矢を放てず、代わりに神渟名川耳が矢を射て殺したとされる（己卯年（紀元前582年?）11月）。
sen.e: It is said that, when they attacked, the hands and feet of Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto trembled with fear and he could not shoot off any arrows and, instead, Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto shot and killed Tagishimimi-no-mikoto (November 582 B.C.?).

It is said that, when they attacked, the hands and feet of Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto trembled with fear and he could not shoot off any arrows and, instead, Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto shot and killed Tagishimimi-no-mikoto (November 582 B.C.?).

It is said that, when they attacked, the hands and feet of Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto trembled with fear and he could not shoot off any arrows and, instead, Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto shot and killed Tagishimimi-no-mikoto (November 582 B.C.?).

sen.j: この失態を恥じた神八井耳は弟を助けて天神地祇を掌り、神渟名川耳が天皇として即位することになった。
sen.e: Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto was ashamed of his blunder and helped his younger brother, and they together ruled the gods in the sky and on the earth, and it was determined that Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto would be enthroned as emperor.

Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto was ashamed of his blunder and helped his younger brother, and they together ruled the gods in the sky and on the earth, and it was determined that Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto would be enthroned as emperor.

Kamuyaimimi-no-mikoto was ashamed of his blunder and helped his younger brother, and together they ruled the gods of heaven and earth, and it was determined that Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto would be enthroned as emperor.
sen.cmt: 他の記事に用語を合わせました。

sen.j: 神渟名川耳は翌年1月に高丘宮にて即位。
sen.e: In January next year, Mamununakawamimi-no-mikoto was enthroned at Takaoka-no-miya.
In January next year, Mamununakawamimi-no-mikoto was enthroned at Takaoka-no-miya.
In January of the following year, Kamununakawamimi-no-mikoto was enthroned at Takaoka-no-miya.
sen.cmt: following yearを使用しスペルを修正しました。

sen.j: なお、綏靖天皇から開化天皇までの初期8人の天皇について、綏靖即位前のこの皇位継承争いを除けば、記紀には系譜（帝紀）のみが伝えられ、事績（旧辞）が全く記されていないため、一般にまとめて「欠史八代」と称される。
sen.e: For the early eight emperors from Emperor Suizei to Emperor Kaika, the two books only describe their genealogy (the Imperial chronology) except the conflict for the Imperial succession happened before the enthronement of the Emperor Suizei, and the books do not describe any of their achievements (description of myths and oral traditions) and, therefore, those eight emperors are in general collectively called "the lost eight generations in the history".

For the early eight emperors from Emperor Suizei to Emperor Kaika, the two books only describe their genealogy (the Imperial chronology) except the conflict for the Imperial succession happened before the enthronement of Emperor Suizei, and the books do not describe any of their achievements (description of myths and oral traditions) and, therefore, those eight emperors are in general collectively called "the lost eight generations in the history".

Except for the conflict over the imperial succession by Emperor Suizei, descriptions given in "Kojiki" and "Nihon Shoki" about the eight emperors from Emperor Suizei to Emperor Kaika are limited to their genealogies (imperial pedigrees) and since no descriptions of their achievements (historical developments) are given, these eight generations of emperors are collectively called the "eight missing generations."
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: なお、南北朝時代 (日本)に安居院澄憲の子孫によって編まれたとされる『神道集』によれば、綏靖天皇には食人の趣味があり、朝夕に7人もの人々を食べ、周囲を恐怖に陥れたという。
sen.e: According to Shintoshu compiled in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) by descendants of Ankyoin Suminori, there was an episode that the Emperor Suizei had a taste for cannibalism, ate as many as seven persons every morning and every evening, and terrified the people around him and, therefore, the people escaped the mishap by confining the emperor in a cave by telling a lie that "fireballs will fall from the heaven", however, this episode was likely to be a fiction because even the existence of the emperor was uncertain..

According to Shintoshu compiled in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) by descendants of Ankyoin Suminori, there was an episode that Emperor Suizei had a taste for cannibalism, ate as many as seven persons every morning and every evening, and terrified the people around him and, therefore, the people escaped the mishap by confining Emperor in a cave by telling a lie that "fireballs will fall from the heaven", however, this episode was likely to be a fiction because even the existence of the Emperor was uncertain..

According to an anecdote in "Shintoshu" (a collection of Shinto legends), which is believed to have been compiled by the descendants of Choken AGUI during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts in Japan, Emperor Suizei had a taste for cannibalism and ate as many as seven people every day, terrifying people around him.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: そのため、人々は「近く火の雨が降る」との虚言を弄し、天皇を岩屋に幽閉して難を逃れたという逸話がある。
sen.e: The anecdote claims that in order to escape the danger, people confined the emperor in a cave by making him believe that fireballs were about to fall from heaven.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、実在が定かでないだけに造作された可能性が高い。
sen.e: However, this anecdote is likely to be fiction, since the existence of the emperor itself is uncertain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: ペルシャの叙事詩『シャー・ナーメ』に登場する暴君ザッハークとの共通性を指摘する説もある。
sen.e: There is an opinion pointing out the common characteristics between the emperor and a tyrant appearing in a Persian epic "Sah Namah".
There is an opinion pointing out the common characteristics between the Emperor and a tyrant appearing in a Persian epic "Sah Namah".
There is an opinion pointing out the common characteristics between the Emperor and Zahhak, a tyrant, appearing in a Persian epic "Sah Namah."

sen.j: 『古事記』には、45歳で没したといい、『日本書紀』によれば、綏靖天皇33年（紀元前549年?）5月に84歳で没したとされる。
sen.e: The book, Kojiki describes that the Emperor Suizei died at the age of 45 and the book, Nihon-Shoki describes that he died at the age of 84 in May 549 B.C. (?).
The book, Kojiki describes that Emperor Suizei died at the age of 45 and the book, Nihon-Shoki describes that he died at the age of 84 in May 549 B.C. (?).
The "Kojiki" describes Emperor Suizei as having died at the age of 45 and "Nihon-Shoki" describes that he died at the age of 84 in May 549 B.C. (?).
sen.cmt: 他の記事と表記を合わせました。

sen.j: 皇居
sen.e: Imperial Palace
Imperial Palace
Imperial Palace

sen.j: 葛城高丘宮（かずらきのたかおかのみや。現在の奈良県御所市森脇か）。
sen.e: Kzuraki-no-takaoka-no-miya (presently, Moriwaki in Mitokoro City in Nara Prefecture?)
Kzuraki-no-takaoka-no-miya (presently, Moriwaki in Mitokoro City in Nara Prefecture?)
Kazuraki-no-takaoka-no-miya (presently, Moriwaki in Mitokoro City in Nara Prefecture?)

sen.j: 『古事記』では「葛城の高岡宮」。
sen.e: This name of the place is wrriten in Kojiki in a somewhoat different way.
This name of the place is written in the Kojiki somewhat differently.
In "Kojiki," it is 'Kazuraki-no-takaoka-no-miya,' while different Chinese characters are used.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と表記を合わせました。

sen.j: 桃花鳥田丘上陵（つきたのおかのうえのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: The Emperor Suizei was laid to rest in Tsukita-no-okanoue-no-misasagi mausoleum.
The Emperor Suizei was laid to rest in Tsukita-no-okanoue-no-misasagi mausoleum.
The Emperor Suizei was laid to rest in Tsukita-no-okanoue-no-misasagi mausoleum.

sen.j: 『古事記』では「御陵は衝田岡（つきだのおか）にあり」とある。
sen.e: In Kojiki, it is written that the mausoleum of the Emperor Suizei is located in Tsukida-no-oka.
In Kojiki, it is written that the mausoleum of the Emperor Suizei is located in Tsukida-no-oka.
In "Kojiki," it is written that 'the mausoleum of the Emperor Suizei is located in Tsukida-no-oka.'
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを補足しました。

sen.j: 現在、同陵は奈良県橿原市四条町字田ノ坪に所在する塚山古墳（古墳古墳の形式一覧・径16m）に比定される。
sen.e: Currently, this mausoleum is compared with and determined to be Tsukayama Tumulus (list of forms of tumulus, diameter: 16 m) which is located in Aza-tanotsubo, Shijo-machi, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.

Currently, this mausoleum is compared with and determined to be Tsukayama Tumulus (list of forms of tumulus, diameter: 16 m) which is located in Aza-tanotsubo, Shijo-machi, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
This mausoleum is estimated to be the Tsukayama Tumulus (a round tumulus with a diameter of 16 m) located in present-day Aza Tanotsubo, Shijo-machi, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 中世には山陵が荒廃して所伝を失い、元禄時代の探陵に諸説生じ慈明寺町のスイセン塚古墳（前方後円墳、墳丘長55m）があてられたりした。
sen.e: In the Medieval Ages, the mausoleum on a mountain was devastated and the records about it handed down until then was lost and, therefore, the search for the mausoleum in Genroku Era produced many opinions including an opinion asserting that Suisenzuka tumulus (a tumulus which is square at its front and rounded in its rear and which is 55-meter long) in Jimyo-cho was the mausoleum and, later on, the above mausoleum was presumed to be the true one in the repair of the mausoleum conducted in the end of Edo Period and the mausoleum was finally determined to be the true one in 1878.

In the Medieval Ages, the mausoleum on the mountain was devastated and the records about it handed down until then lost and, therefore, the search for the mausoleum during the Genroku Era produced many opinions including one asserting that the Suisenzuka tumulus (a tumulus which is square at its front and rounded in its rear and which is 55-meter long) in Jimyo-cho was the mausoleum and, later on, the above mausoleum was presumed to be the actual one. During the repair of the mausoleum conducted in the end of Edo Period it was finally determined to be the true one in 1878.

In the Medieval Ages, the mausoleum on the mountain was devastated and the records about it handed down until then lost and therefore, the search for the mausoleum during the Genroku Era produced many opinions including one asserting that the Suisenzuka tumulus (a tumulus which is a large keyhole-shaped tomb mound and is 55 meters long) in Jimyoji-cho was the mausoleum and, later on, the above mausoleum was presumed to be the actual one.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 幕末修陵に際して現陵を擬し、明治11年（1878年）治定。
sen.e: During the repair of the mausoleum conducted in the end of Edo period it was finally determined to be the actual one in 1878.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
